reviewText: This movie is just plain weird. I'm not sure I even know what to think of it.Well, it's the only movie I've seen involving cartoon heroes, live-action, rubber suit monsters and a bizarre truck/tank/aircraft thingy. It's a unique movie, at any rate. Despite a large amount of repitition, I didn't get bored watching it.
summary: The weirdest movie I've ever seen!

reviewText: I came across a VHS copy of this film several years ago at a spot we used to have in Chicago’s Wicker Park area called HOUSE OF MONSTERS. That shop no longer exists, but I bought the VHS copy of this film as I am a huge Kaiju fan (as I assume anyone even bothering to read this review is). Most of the other reviewers on here have given a good description of this film, so I’ll throw in my two cents just for the record.My understanding is that this film is an edited-together mash-up of four episodes of a Japanese fantasy series called AIZENBORG(sp?).  In fact, if I am remembering correctly, I believe the name AIZENBORG can be seen in one or two scenes on the side of the ship that the male and female cyborg protagonists combine to become… Or maybe it was the name on the side of their headquarters… I can’t exactly recall, only that the name does appear briefly in a couple scenes.In any case, I did get somewhat of a kick out of the mixing of genres (kaiju/suitmation, sci-fi, anime). I found the goofy narrative enjoyable enough. And Kaiju fans will recognize the film’s main antagonist, King Tyranno, as the T-Rex from the Toho-Rankin Bass production THE LAST DINOSAUR. However, this was a mid-to-late 70s TOHO production, from the shoddy ‘Diagoro vs. Goliath’ school of special effects, or some of the late 70s ULTRA-hero series, which lacked the fine effects work of the earliest ULTRA shows (ULTRA Q, ULTRA MAN, ULTRA SEVEN).  So I found the monster attacks and the battles cheap-looking and shoddy, compared to what we know TOHO to be capable of.  Even though this was clearly marketed toward kids, I have seen many TOHO shows where the special effects were far more dynamic than the sub-par effects we get here. Because of that, I cannot rate this film any higher than THREE STARS.  However, if you are a true KAIJU fan, I imagine you will find something redeemable in this wacky film. It is a semi-classic in its obscurity, and probably only collectable for kaiju completists. If your kids like shows like Power Rangers, they may well get a kick out of this.
summary: SUPER ATTACK ON YOUR SENSES--just Go With It!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film is jarring.  We first see a bunch of giant dinosaurs (men in rubber suits) emerge from the Earth and declare, in English, that the humans must die.  Then, in a camera shot of a forest, we see cartoon animals and then dogs.  The mixing of styles is odd.The film is actually four chapters about the Gemini force who cut their teeth on the menace of the Super Monsters (super-powered, giant, telepathic, talking dinosaurs).Part one has a T-rex mutate dogs into monsters.  The Gemini team members Jim and Jem combine their bionic parts to become the super being Gemini (no, I'm serious).  Their vehicle also changes and seems like it doesn't need Gemini to be powerful.Part two has a pterodactyl turn bats into giant monsters (their size varies from scene to scene from normal to a few feet).In part three, a stegosaurus turns the rats into monsters.In part four we have to giant dinosaurs, a triceratops (actually a styracosaurus) and a T-rex/allosaurus type.There is no real ending to the story.  The dinosaur leader, Tyrannus, is still around, but there is no teaser about future battles.Much of the story is pretty silly and standard.  We have the comic relief science guys, the heavy-eyebrowed hero, transformations, fantastic vehicles (the main one of which seems to exist only for launching and never gets involved in the conflicts), rubber-suit monsters, and bad dialogue.Overall, this makes the Power Rangers look like Citizen Kane.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm a big fan of giant monster movies and shows "Godzilla, Ultraman" and was very disappointed with this movie. Dinosaurs have survived for millions of years below the Earth's surface. They have become more intelligent than humans and have decided to take back the surface annihilating all humans in the process. The only thing that can stop them is a group of four super-powered teenagers "two of them look like old men in their 60's". The younger male and female can somehow combine themselves to become one cyborg being/vehicle called Gemini to fight the "terrifying" monsters. The movie is a mixture of live action, suitmation & animation. The animation is very crude, the rubber-suited monster are worse than what you see in Ultraman, and the live action is something out of the Thunderbirds. I believe the film was originally a tv show that a few of the episodes were combined to make this 83 minute movie, so there really isn't any satisfying conclusion to the story.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Read about this on the Bad Movie Website and just had to see it for myself. I don't know how much was lost in translation from the Japanese, but am well aware that most anime - like most of anything else - is mediocre. This is just south of mediocre.The DVD is a good copy, both visually and aurally. However, what it's copying may not have been worth the effort.It's worth viewing to see how multiple techniques - cell animation, stop-motion animation and live action with guys in rubber monster suits - were integrated, but otherwise give it a miss.
summary: Review of _Attack of the Super Monsters_
Title: N/A

reviewText: I love this because it's so bad, I'm a huge monster movie fanatic and I could of done without the animation as it cheapens the episodes. Classic models (buildings/vehicles/miniatures/ect.), men in rubber suits and horrible animation. 3 star due to VHS to DVD transfer not a care was given to the transfer. My VHS version is 100% better than this production and I'm not surprised as this is a SUBSTANCE release and in the past I have not been happy with their quality. I will never buy anything from SUBSTANCE again, not quality worthy. DVD cover/back art is cheesy and looks like a 2nd grader did it. If you love cheesy monster flicks then this is for you, just wish SUBSTANCE would take some pride in their productions.
Title: N/A
